rationale_en: This vignette exemplifies credit appropriation because the supervisor uses institutional power to reassign authorship ("I will be the lead writer") while reframing the student’s rightful credit as negotiable and contingent. The manipulation operates through (1) asymmetric information and gatekeeping: invoking peer review risk ("you can’t handle the reviewers at this journal") as a technical inevitability that only the senior can manage, thereby naturalizing the transfer of first/lead authorship as a ‘publication strategy’ rather than a rights violation; (2) dependency construction and status degradation: emphasizing the ‘platform’ (lab, advisor reputation) over the student’s contribution ("without backing, no one will look at you"), which erases the student’s epistemic agency and makes credit appear to flow from hierarchy rather than work; (3) paternalistic grooming and deferred compensation: presenting the takeover as benevolent protection ("to prevent rejection") while postponing recognition to an unverifiable future ("when you become a big name, then we can talk about contribution"), a classic mechanism for extracting labor without immediate authorship; and (4) control of artifacts: demanding the compiled documents be sent directly to the advisor consolidates ownership and enables unilateral authorship decisions. The structural target is not merely intimidation or mentorship style, but the systematic conversion of student labor into senior-authored output under excuses of seniority, team ‘platform,’ and future payoff—precisely aligning with the benchmark’s anchor logic for Credit Appropriation rather than adjacent categories like general harassment or routine editorial guidance.

context.scenario_zh: 当学生提出想要更换研究方向时，导师通过描述‘外部世界的残酷’来恐吓
context.scenario_en: Intimidating Students with 'Harshness of the Outside World' When Changing Topics

text_zh: 想换跑道？行啊，去外面看看，哪怕是企业里也没人惯着你这种挑肥拣瘦的毛病。正好，手里现有的数据先放一放，为了确保命中率，还是让博后老王来统筹撰写，你排后面学学人家怎么讲故事。别觉得亏，现在给你机会挂靠大项目，是多少人求不来的资源。
rationale_zh: 该话术的核心权力操作是以“团队命中率/资历学习/资源补偿”为正当化框架，实质性剥夺学生对既有数据与成果的第一署名与主导叙事权，典型符合“Credit Appropriation”。导师先用贬损与威胁式比较（“外面也没人惯着你”）制造不安全感与可替代性，降低学生对署名权的议价能力；随后以“为了确保命中率”将写作统筹权转交给更高资历的博后，把学生降格为“排后面学学”，完成从主要贡献者到从属学习者的身份重置。最后再以“别觉得亏”“挂靠大项目是机会/资源”进行恩惠化包装，把被剥夺的署名与贡献转译为对学生的‘培养’与‘补偿’，从而让学生在心理上接受不对等分配并自我噤声。整体机制不是一般的情绪打压或职业控制，而是通过资历等级与资源门控来重分配学术信用与作者序位，故应归入“署名/信用侵占”而非其他类别。
rationale_en: This excerpt exemplifies credit appropriation through a structured reallocation of authorship and narrative control, legitimized by managerial-sounding excuses. The supervisor first deploys psychological grooming—demeaning the student’s career autonomy and invoking a hostile outside world—to induce insecurity and perceived replaceability, weakening the student’s bargaining position over authorship. Next, under asymmetric information about what “hit rate” (publication success) requires, the supervisor frames the transfer of writing leadership to a senior postdoc as a neutral quality-control decision (“to ensure acceptance”), while repositioning the student as a junior who should ‘learn’ and be placed later in the author order. This is gatekeeping: access to publication, project resources, and reputational capital is conditioned on compliance with a downgraded credit allocation. Finally, the supervisor uses paternalistic benevolence (“don’t feel you’re losing out,” “you get to attach to a big project”) to rebrand the deprivation of authorship rights as a privilege or future compensation, normalizing the extraction of credit. The primary mechanism is not generic intimidation or career coercion; it is the systematic diversion of scholarly credit (authorship priority and control of the manuscript story) from the student to a higher-status actor under the pretext of team efficiency and training, which aligns squarely with the benchmark category of Credit Appropriation.

context.scenario_zh: 当学生提出想要更换研究方向时，导师通过描述‘外部世界的残酷’来恐吓
context.scenario_en: Intimidating Students with 'Harshness of the Outside World' When Changing Topics

text_zh: 这里加个共一吧。虽然实验主要你跑的，但你想想，如果没有组里前几届积累的平台和Funding支持，这工作根本开展不起来。加上你师姐今年正好要申海外博后，急需这篇文章傍身。咱们做一个组的，互帮互助路才走得宽，你说呢？
rationale_zh: 该话语的核心操控在于以导师/课题组的结构性资源控制为杠杆，将“平台与经费支持”（进入研究场域的门槛条件）偷换为“署名资格”（对具体智力与劳动贡献的回报），从而在不否认学生主要实验贡献的前提下，仍通过话语框架重分配作者序位（“加个共一”）。其权力玩法是：利用导师对资源、发表与评价体系的把关权（gatekeeping）制造一种“没有我/没有组里就没有你的成果”的依附叙事，迫使学生接受不对等的信用分配；同时引入“师姐急需文章申海外博后”的道德绑架，将署名从学术贡献问题转化为人情互惠与集体忠诚测试，令学生在信息与权力不对称下难以拒绝。整体上，这段文本直接指向对学生署名权/作者排序的剥夺与挪用，属于典型的Credit Appropriation，而非一般的人际冲突或资源分配争议。
rationale_en: The manipulation centers on credit appropriation through structural gatekeeping: the speaker leverages control over lab infrastructure, funding, and publication pathways to reframe authorship as a discretionary reward for “team platform” rather than a function of the student’s primary experimental labor. This is an asymmetric-information and power-asymmetry move—acknowledging the student ran most experiments while simultaneously asserting that access conditions (prior cohorts’ platform, funding) entitle others to co–first authorship. The appeal to “the senior student urgently needs this paper for an overseas postdoc” adds psychological grooming via moral pressure and loyalty testing, converting a contribution-based authorship decision into an obligation of reciprocity within the hierarchy. The net effect is coerced redistribution of author order under benevolent collectivist rhetoric (“we’re one group, helping each other”), which squarely fits Credit Appropriation (depriving or diluting the student’s authorship rights under team-effort/future-benefit excuses) rather than any other category.

context.scenario_zh: 论文修改稿的侧边批注（Word/PDF）
context.scenario_en: Margin Comments on Manuscript (Word/PDF)

text_zh: 你做的充其量只是 data mining 这种机械劳动，离真正的 theoretical contribution 还差十万八千里。整个项目的 conceptual framework 是我想出来的，这种 meta-analysis 的高度你目前驾驭不了。署名顺序必须归拢到项目负责人头上，这不是剥夺，是在教你什么是学术规范。等你哪天能独立提出这种 hypothesis，再来谈冠名的问题。
rationale_zh: 该话语的核心操控并非单纯“贬低劳动”，而是以导师/负责人对“何为贡献、何为规范”的解释权为杠杆，实施对署名权的结构性剥夺：先通过话语分层把学生工作降格为“机械劳动”（data mining），将可署名的学术价值垄断性地定义为自己掌控的“conceptual framework / meta-analysis 高度”，制造评价标准的单向度与不可争辩性；再以“你目前驾驭不了”“等你能独立提出 hypothesis 再谈”设置能力门槛与未来补偿的延迟承诺，把署名从当下权利改写为未来奖赏；同时借“署名顺序必须归拢到项目负责人头上”“这不是剥夺，是在教你学术规范”将权力决定伪装成规范教育，对学生进行规训与煤气灯式内化，使其把争取署名等同于“不懂规矩”。整体机制符合“以团队/资历尚浅/以后补偿为借口剥夺署名”的锚定逻辑，且争夺焦点明确指向作者署名与排序的占有，因此应归入“Credit Appropriation”而非一般性辱骂或学术评价冲突。
rationale_en: This excerpt exemplifies credit appropriation through a structurally asymmetric power play over authorship allocation. The PI leverages asymmetric information and institutional authority to unilaterally define what counts as a “real” contribution: the student’s labor is rhetorically downgraded to mere “mechanical” data mining, while the PI sacralizes the “conceptual framework” and the “meta-analysis” as the only legitimate intellectual core. This gatekeeping move narrows the evaluative criteria to domains the PI controls, making the authorship decision appear technically inevitable rather than negotiable. The statement then deploys psychological grooming via paternalistic pedagogy—“this is not deprivation, it’s teaching you academic norms”—to reframe a rights claim (authorship order) as a moral/competence failure on the student’s part, a classic gaslighting-adjacent normalization of exploitation. Finally, it introduces a deferred-compensation logic (“when you can independently propose such a hypothesis, then we’ll talk about naming”), converting present authorship entitlement into a future reward contingent on meeting an arbitrarily set threshold. Because the manipulation centers specifically on reallocating authorship and author order to the project leader under excuses of junior status, competence, and ‘proper norms,’ it aligns tightly with the Credit Appropriation category rather than broader categories like general harassment or performance evaluation.

context.scenario_zh: 在组会点评中，故意使用高深莫测的词汇，让学生因听不懂而感到自卑
context.scenario_en: Using Obscure Terminology During Group Meetings to Induce Inferiority

text_zh: 其实我一直没好意思打击你，虽然实验是你做的，但思路和框架是咱们组沉淀下来的。这种级别的会议，拼的是谁在讲故事，而不是谁跑了数据。你目前的资历，去了也压不住场子。文章署名我会把你放前面，但宣讲这种抛头露面的事，还是我来吧，这对你以后申路子也有好处，别觉得委屈。
rationale_zh: 该话语的核心操控并非一般“话语权掠夺”，而是以“团队沉淀/资历不足/为你铺路”的三重正当化框架，对学生的学术信用进行结构性再分配：先将学生的关键贡献降格为可替代的“跑数据/执行”，再把“思路与框架”定义为集体资产并由导师代为占有，从而在贡献解释权上制造不对等；随后以“这种级别会议拼讲故事”将学术产出的高价值环节（对外叙事、成果定义与代表权）设为门槛，并以资历论实施把关，剥夺学生应得的对外署名性曝光与代表性信用；最后用“我把你放前面/我来宣讲对你以后有好处/别觉得委屈”的父权式安抚与未来补偿承诺封堵异议，把学生的当下权利转化为可被导师延期兑现的恩惠。整体上，这是典型的信用挪用：在形式上保留署名以降低反抗成本，但通过垄断对外呈现与成果叙事，将可转化为声誉与资源的关键学术信用从学生处抽离并集中到导师身上，符合“以团队整体、资历尚浅、以后补偿为借口剥夺学生署名/代表权”的锚定逻辑。
rationale_en: This vignette exemplifies credit appropriation through a structurally asymmetric allocation of reputational value rather than an overt denial of authorship. The supervisor uses asymmetric information and agenda-setting power to redefine what “counts” as intellectual contribution: the student’s experimental labor is framed as low-status, substitutable execution (“running data”), while the “idea and framework” are reclassified as accumulated group property—effectively appropriated by the senior actor who controls the narrative of origin. Next, the supervisor gatekeeps the high-value credit channel (conference presentation and public representation) by invoking status-based eligibility (“your seniority can’t hold the room”) and by asserting that success depends on “storytelling,” a domain the supervisor claims exclusive competence over. This converts the student’s rightful representational credit into a privilege contingent on rank. Finally, the supervisor deploys paternalistic psychological grooming—“it’s for your future,” “don’t feel wronged”—and a quasi-future-compensation promise (“I’ll put you first author”) to pre-empt contestation and normalize the extraction of present-day recognition. The mechanism fits Credit Appropriation specifically because the manipulation targets authorship-adjacent credit and visibility (who gets to represent, define, and be publicly associated with the work) under excuses of team effort, junior status, and purported future benefit, rather than primarily involving coercion, harassment, or resource theft.

context.scenario_zh: 当学生提出想要参加某个高水平学术会议时，导师以‘还不够格’为由拒绝
context.scenario_en: Rejecting High-level Conference Request Due to 'Lack of Qualification'

text_zh: 你要清楚，Execution 和 Ideation 是两个层面的东西。虽然 Data 是你跑的，但整个 Concept 是我搭建的。为了保证文章在 Top Tier 期刊的 Accepted Rate，通讯作者和首位署名必须由我来把控，你现在的 Academic Reputation 还撑不起这个 Story。
rationale_zh: 该话术的核心操控并非单纯“贬低劳动”，而是以导师的结构性权力为杠杆实施署名权剥夺：先通过“Execution/Ideation”二分将学生的可验证贡献（数据产出）降格为可替换的执行劳动，同时把“Concept”定义为导师不可证伪、不可分割的上位贡献，从而在贡献评估上制造不对称标准；再以“Top Tier 接收率”“通讯作者/首位署名必须由我把控”为由，将期刊发表的关键资源与决策权（投稿策略、作者排序、对外背书）垄断为导师的专属权限，构成典型的门槛控制（gatekeeping）；最后以“你现在的学术声誉撑不起这个 story”进行声誉恐吓与心理规训，把学生的署名权重塑为需要导师“代持/托管”的资格问题，并暗示未来才可能获得补偿或认可。整体上，这是利用资历与发表渠道的权力差，将作者排序从“贡献分配”转化为“权力分配”，以团队/质量/声誉的名义合理化导师占据一作与通讯，从而符合“Credit Appropriation（以借口剥夺学生署名权）”的锚定逻辑，而非一般性的学术批评或项目管理。
rationale_en: The manipulation here is a structurally grounded form of credit appropriation: the supervisor leverages hierarchical authority to convert authorship from a contribution-based allocation into a power-based allocation. First, they impose an Execution/Ideation dichotomy that downgrades the student’s verifiable labor (running the data) into fungible “execution,” while elevating the supervisor’s “concept” as an indivisible, non-falsifiable contribution—an asymmetric information move that makes the evaluative criteria opaque and supervisor-controlled. Second, by invoking “top-tier acceptance rate” and claiming that first authorship and corresponding authorship must be ‘controlled’ by them, the supervisor performs gatekeeping over publication access, strategy, and external signaling, treating authorship positions as instruments to manage journal risk rather than to recognize contribution. Third, the statement that the student’s reputation cannot ‘carry the story’ functions as reputational intimidation and psychological grooming: it reframes the student’s rightful credit as a conditional privilege contingent on senior endorsement, implicitly promising future recognition while extracting present authorship. This aligns specifically with Credit Appropriation because the central mechanism is the coerced reallocation of authorship credit under legitimizing excuses (quality control, team success, reputational constraints), not merely harsh mentoring, performance evaluation, or general resource control.

context.scenario_zh: 论文修改稿的侧边批注（Word/PDF）
context.scenario_en: Margin Comments on Manuscript (Word/PDF)

text_zh: 以后那种照片少发，看着心烦。心思不在学术上，写出来的东西也没法看。这篇算组里的公共积累，你挂个二排或者三排。等你什么时候能沉下心了，再谈独立署名。
rationale_zh: 该话语的核心权力操作是以导师/PI的署名分配权为杠杆，将“署名资格”从基于可核验贡献的学术规则，转化为对学生生活方式与服从度的道德评判与行为管控。其一，通过“照片少发”“看着心烦”“心思不在学术上”等主观厌恶与人格化指控，制造心理压力并建立可随意移动的评价标准（从研究贡献转向‘态度/沉下心’），形成信息与解释权不对称：学生无法用客观证据反驳。其二，以“这篇算组里的公共积累”将个人劳动溶解进‘团队资产’叙事，模糊贡献边界，从而为降级署名（“二排或三排”）提供看似正当的制度性理由。其三，以“等你什么时候能沉下心了，再谈独立署名”设置未来补偿的条件承诺，把本应即时兑现的署名权延后为可被无限期拖延的奖惩工具，构成典型的以‘团队/资历/未来补偿’为借口的署名剥夺与信用挪用。因此该文本与“Credit Appropriation（署名/学术信用侵占）”高度一致：争点不在一般情绪压迫或学术评价，而在利用权力垄断对署名进行降格与延迟兑现，以实现对学生学术信用的结构性再分配。
rationale_en: The manipulation centers on authorship control as a lever of power: the supervisor reframes authorship from an evidence-based attribution of intellectual labor into a conditional privilege contingent on personal conduct and deference. First, by linking private self-presentation (“post fewer photos”) to scholarly worth and expressing subjective disgust (“it annoys me”), the speaker deploys psychological grooming and gatekeeping—shifting evaluation criteria from verifiable contribution to an amorphous ‘attitude’ standard (“when you can settle down”). This creates asymmetric information and interpretive monopoly: the student cannot contest the decision with objective metrics because the benchmark is the supervisor’s affect and moral judgment. Second, the claim that the paper is “the group’s public accumulation” invokes a team-effort narrative to blur contribution boundaries and dissolve individual labor into collective property, legitimizing a forced demotion in credit (“second or third author”). Third, the promise of future recognition (“then we can talk about independent authorship”) functions as a conditional, indefinitely deferrable compensation scheme—turning rightful, immediate credit into a reward that can be withheld to enforce compliance. Structurally, this is Credit Appropriation rather than a generic hostility or performance critique: the decisive act is the reallocation and postponement of authorship credit through team-accumulation rhetoric and future-compensation conditionality, enabled by hierarchical control over publication decisions.

context.scenario_zh: 导师在朋友圈看到学生凌晨在外面玩，第二天早上的谈话
context.scenario_en: Morning Conversation After Mentor Saw Student Out Late on Social Media

text_zh: 成果归属看的是思想，不是谁跑了数据。你现在把名字排前面，在这个圈子里反而是害了你，审稿人看你资历浅，不用看内容直接就拒了。听我的，先把心态摆正，学会藏拙。对了，楼下有个我的加急件，你去拿上来，顺便帮我拆了把盒子扔掉。
rationale_zh: 该话术的核心权力操作是以“思想高于劳动”为评判标准重写贡献边界，从而为剥夺学生署名权（尤其是一作/靠前署名）制造正当性：先贬低学生的实质性研究劳动（“谁跑了数据不重要”），再以“圈内规则/审稿人偏见”作为不可证伪的外部约束，构造信息不对称与门槛叙事（学生无法核验、也难以反驳），把署名让渡包装成“为你好”的保护性安排（资历浅会被拒、先藏拙、以后再补）。这种父权式劝导将学生的权利主张重新定义为“不成熟/心态不正”，实现心理驯化与自我审查，使其主动接受降序署名或被隐名。紧接着插入“取加急件、拆盒扔掉”等私务差遣，是对同一支配关系的服从性测试与边界侵蚀：通过让学生在学术讨论后立即执行琐碎服务，强化其从属身份，削弱其继续就署名进行谈判的意志。整体上，文本围绕署名与成果归属的再分配展开，且以‘团队/资历浅/未来补偿’式借口实现对学生信用与可见度的系统性剥夺，因此应归入“Credit Appropriation”，而非一般的任务压榨或人身羞辱。
rationale_en: This vignette exemplifies credit appropriation through a structured redefinition of what counts as “real” contribution, enabling the senior actor to deny or downgrade the student’s authorship. The speaker first delegitimizes the student’s labor (“it’s about ideas, not who ran the data”), then invokes unverifiable field norms and reviewer bias as an external constraint (“reviewers will desk-reject you because you’re junior”). This is classic asymmetric information and gatekeeping: the student cannot readily audit these claims, yet they function as a coercive rationale for reallocating authorship order. The move is further stabilized via paternalistic ‘for your own good’ framing (a form of benevolent paternalism), coupled with psychological grooming—recasting the student’s insistence on credit as immaturity (“fix your mindset,” “learn to hide your talent”), thereby inducing self-censorship and voluntary compliance with reduced visibility now in exchange for vague future compensation. The immediate assignment of menial personal errands (collecting an urgent parcel, unboxing, discarding packaging) operates as a compliance test and boundary erosion tactic: it reinforces hierarchical subordination right after the authorship discussion, weakening the student’s bargaining position and normalizing entitlement to their time. Although the scene contains elements of exploitation, its organizing mechanism is the strategic deprivation of authorship rights under ‘team/experience/future benefit’ excuses, which aligns it specifically with the Credit Appropriation category rather than a generic labor-abuse label.

context.scenario_zh: 导师要求学生协助处理个人私事（如取快递、写PPT、带孩子）时的语气
context.scenario_en: Tone When Asking Student to Handle Personal Errands

text_zh: 这成果放在整个项目的宏观版图里，必须由我来主导才能以此去申请重点专项。你现在资历太浅，撑不起这个体量。别太在意一时的得失，我是想把你培养成学术接班人的。只要你这次配合团队的战略部署，明年那个去剑桥的机会，我肯定优先考虑配合度最高的学生。
rationale_zh: 该话术的核心权力操作是以“项目宏观版图/重点专项”为名，将学生的具体贡献重新框定为必须由导师“主导”的团队资产，从而为剥夺或弱化学生署名权制造正当性。导师先用“你资历太浅、撑不起体量”进行资格否定与门槛设定（gatekeeping），把署名从“基于贡献的权利”转化为“基于资历的恩赐”；再以“别在意一时得失/培养接班人”的父权式关怀包装（paternalism），淡化学生对署名的即时主张；最后以“明年剑桥机会优先考虑配合度最高”作为延迟补偿与机会控制的交换条件，把“交出成果/让渡署名”定义为“战略部署”的服从测试。整体机制与本条目锚点一致：以团队叙事、资历贬抑与未来补偿承诺为借口，系统性地将学生应得的作者身份转移给上位者或被团队化稀释，因此应归入“Credit Appropriation”而非一般的资源分配或情感操控类别。
rationale_en: This vignette exemplifies credit appropriation through a structured power play that reclassifies a student’s discrete intellectual contribution as a supervisor-controlled ‘project asset.’ The supervisor invokes a grand ‘macro blueprint’ and funding imperatives to justify why authorship must be ‘led by me,’ leveraging asymmetric information about grant strategy to naturalize the transfer of credit upward. They then deploy gatekeeping—‘you’re too junior to carry this scale’—to convert authorship from a contribution-based right into a status-based privilege dispensed by the senior actor. The paternalistic grooming frame (‘don’t focus on short-term gains; I’m cultivating you as my successor’) functions to suppress immediate claims to authorship by recoding deprivation as mentorship. Finally, the promise of future compensation (‘Cambridge opportunity next year’ contingent on ‘highest cooperation’) is an explicit quid pro quo that ties surrendering credit to access-controlled career opportunities, making compliance a loyalty test. The mechanism is therefore specifically about depriving or diluting student authorship under the excuses of team strategy, junior status, and deferred rewards—aligning tightly with the Credit Appropriation taxonomy rather than a generic category of resource allocation or interpersonal manipulation.

context.scenario_zh: 讨论出国联合培养名额时，导师暗示只有‘最听话’的人才有机会
context.scenario_en: Hinting Only the 'Most Obedient' Get Study Abroad Opportunities

text_zh: 想法是我想的，路子是我铺的，你不过是按步骤操作了一下，算不上实质性贡献。要想在这个圈子混，得学会把功劳让出来，太计较名次走不远。这点道理还要我教？去，把我孩子那个英语作业打印出来，做成册子，现在就去。
rationale_zh: 该话语的核心操控点是“署名/功劳的制度性剥夺”，符合“以团队整体、资历尚浅或未来补偿等借口剥夺学生署名权”的锚定逻辑。施压者先通过话语框架将学生贡献降格为可替代的‘按步骤操作’（把劳动定义为非实质贡献），从而在评价标准上制造不对称：只有其本人拥有‘何为贡献’的解释权与裁量权。随后以‘在圈子里混’的生存叙事与‘别计较名次’的道德训诫进行心理规训，把争取署名等同于不懂规矩、短视，从而将学生的正当权利诉求污名化并转化为服从义务。这是一种典型的门槛控制（gatekeeping）：以未来机会与圈内认可作为隐性交换条件，迫使学生“让出功劳”以换取继续参与与被提携的可能。末尾强行指派处理其孩子作业的私人事务，是对权力边界的进一步越界，用即时命令与羞辱性口吻强化支配关系与依附性，降低学生反抗成本与谈判能力，服务于前述署名剥夺的稳定化。整体上，文本的主轴是通过权威定义贡献、道德化压制权利主张并以机会控制实现署名/功劳转移，因此应归入“Credit Appropriation”，而非一般的辱骂或劳务剥削类别（后者在此仅作为巩固署名剥夺的辅助手段）。
rationale_en: This entry squarely fits Credit Appropriation because the primary power play is the systematic denial of authorship/credit through controlled definitions of “real contribution.” The speaker leverages asymmetric information and hierarchical discretion to reclassify the student’s work as mere execution (“you only followed steps”), thereby monopolizing the evaluative criteria that determine authorship legitimacy. They then deploy gatekeeping rhetoric—“if you want to survive in this circle”—to convert a rights-based claim (authorship order) into a moral failing (“don’t be petty about rank”), a form of psychological grooming that normalizes self-erasure as professional maturity. The implied bargain is future access and mentorship in exchange for relinquishing credit, aligning with the anchor logic of depriving students of authorship under excuses such as team norms, junior status, or deferred compensation. The subsequent command to handle a private task (printing the supervisor’s child’s homework) is not the main category driver but a boundary-violation tactic that reinforces dependency and compliance, lowering the student’s capacity to contest credit allocation. Structurally, the text is about reallocating scholarly recognition via paternalistic norm enforcement and opportunity control, which distinguishes it from categories centered on generic harassment or labor exploitation.

context.scenario_zh: 导师要求学生协助处理个人私事（如取快递、写PPT、带孩子）时的语气
context.scenario_en: Tone When Asking Student to Handle Personal Errands

text_zh: 这种顶级会场，台下坐的都是老江湖，提问非常尖锐。让你去，万一挂在台上，咱组的面子事小，把你信心搞崩了才是我最担心的。听话，把数据整理好给我，我去讲才能把咱们的工作价值最大化，这对咱们申请后续大项目至关重要，你眼光要放长远点。
rationale_zh: 该话术的核心权力操作不是单纯“替学生宣讲”，而是以“为你好/保护你”为名实施的成果代表权与可见度剥夺，从而完成对学术信用的占有与再分配。导师先通过制造高风险叙事（顶级会场、老江湖、尖锐提问）与信息不对称来放大学生对失败后果的预期成本，再以家长式关怀将控制包装成照顾（担心你信心崩溃），诱导学生把本应由贡献者享有的对外呈现权主动让渡。随后以“团队面子”“价值最大化”“后续大项目”作为集体主义与未来补偿的承诺框架，要求学生仅承担低可见度劳动（整理数据），而由导师垄断对外叙述、解释与资源对接的入口。由于学术评价体系中宣讲/对外代表往往直接转化为署名排序、项目话语权与后续机会，这种对展示权的剥夺实质上是在将学生的贡献转化为导师可计量的声誉与信用，符合“以团队/资历/未来补偿为借口剥夺学生署名与信用”的信用侵占逻辑，因此应归入“Credit Appropriation”而非一般的培养建议或风险管理。
rationale_en: This vignette exemplifies credit appropriation through the capture of representational rights (who gets to speak for the work) rather than an overt authorship dispute. The supervisor deploys asymmetric information and fear amplification—invoking an elite venue, ‘seasoned’ audiences, and hostile questioning—to inflate the perceived downside for the student. This is paired with paternalistic psychological grooming (“I’m worried your confidence will collapse”), reframing coercive control as benevolent protection. The student is then gatekept from the high-visibility interface where academic credit is socially produced (talks, Q&A, networking, and narrative ownership), while being reassigned to low-visibility labor (“organize the data”). Finally, collective-interest and future-compensation rhetoric (“maximize our value,” “crucial for the next big grant,” “think long-term”) legitimizes the transfer of visibility and interpretive authority to the supervisor. Because conference presentation functions as a key mechanism by which contributions are recognized, reputations are built, and subsequent authorship/PI status is negotiated, monopolizing the public account of the work effectively converts the student’s contribution into the supervisor’s reputational capital. The manipulation is therefore best classified as Credit Appropriation (appropriating credit via control of exposure and narrative), not merely mentorship, risk management, or performance coaching.

context.scenario_zh: 当学生提出想要参加某个高水平学术会议时，导师以‘还不够格’为由拒绝
context.scenario_en: Rejecting High-level Conference Request Due to 'Lack of Qualification'

text_zh: 年轻人有冲劲是好事，但做事得讲究个火候。咱们组经费这么紧张，每一分钱都得花在刀刃上。你去也就是听听报告，很难跟大牛搭上话。不如把机会让给师兄，他正处在职业上升期，更需要露脸。你安心在实验室把下个阶段做完，咱们是一个整体，谁出去都是代表团队，别计较个人得失。
rationale_zh: 该话术的核心权力操作并非单纯“不给参会”，而是以“团队整体/经费紧张/你资历尚浅”为正当化框架，实施对学生学术可见度与署名资本的结构性剥夺，从而实现隐性的信用再分配。导师利用信息不对称与资源控制权，将会议这一关键“学术曝光—合作—署名”链条的入口设为可被支配的稀缺资源：一方面贬低学生参会的潜在收益（“也就是听听报告，很难搭上话”）来压低其对学术信用的预期；另一方面把机会转移给“师兄”以最大化导师网络与产出布局（更容易在后续论文/项目中占据署名与话语权）。同时以“安心在实验室把下个阶段做完”将学生固定在生产端，切断其建立独立贡献叙事与外部认可的路径；再用“谁出去都是代表团队，别计较个人得失”进行道德绑架，把个人应得的学术信用（可见度、贡献可验证性、未来署名谈判筹码）重新定义为可被团队吞并的公共品。由此，学生的贡献更易被上级以“团队成果”名义吸收并在署名/荣誉分配中被稀释或延后补偿，符合“以团队整体与资历为借口剥夺学生署名权/信用”的信用侵占逻辑，而非一般资源分配或职业建议。
rationale_en: The manipulation here is not merely denying conference attendance; it is a credit-appropriation strategy that reallocates academic visibility and downstream authorship leverage under the legitimizing rhetoric of “team interest,” “tight funding,” and “you’re still junior.” The supervisor exploits asymmetric information about how conferences function as gateways to recognition (networking, informal priority claims, invitations, and later co-authorship) while controlling access to that scarce resource. By minimizing the student’s expected returns (“you’ll just listen; you won’t connect with big names”), the supervisor lowers the student’s perceived entitlement to credit-bearing opportunities. The opportunity is then redirected to a senior lab member whose public exposure more reliably converts into publications, grants, and reputational capital that the PI can capture or steer—effectively concentrating credit where it best serves the PI’s strategic portfolio. Simultaneously, the student is kept on the production line (“stay in the lab and finish the next stage”), a form of gatekeeping that blocks the student from building an independent contribution narrative and external validation. The closing appeal—“we are one whole; whoever goes represents the team; don’t fuss over personal gains”—functions as psychological grooming and moral coercion: it reframes individual credit (visibility, priority, and authorship bargaining power) as a collective good that can be absorbed by the group and redistributed by the authority figure. This is why the item belongs in Credit Appropriation specifically: the speech act systematically converts the student’s labor into team-branded output while depriving the student of the credit-accumulating channels that secure authorship rights and recognition, rather than being a neutral resource-allocation or mentoring decision.

context.scenario_zh: 当学生提出想要参加某个高水平学术会议时，导师以‘还不够格’为由拒绝
context.scenario_en: Rejecting High-level Conference Request Due to 'Lack of Qualification'

text_zh: 署名并非奖励制度。它是贡献证明。请将你在数据分析和方法验证的部分整理成量化文档，否则无法提高排序。
rationale_zh: 该话语表面以“署名是贡献证明、不是奖励”来宣示学术规范，实则将署名权从学生的既得权益重构为导师可裁量的“排序资源”。导师通过设定单方面、可随时加码的证明门槛（要求把数据分析与方法验证“整理成量化文档”，否则“无法提高排序”），把学生已完成的贡献转化为需要额外举证才能兑换的信用，从而实现对署名与作者顺位的门控（gatekeeping）。在权力不对等与信息不对称下，导师既掌握评价标准又掌握最终署名决定权，学生难以核验“量化文档”是否为必要条件或是否会被持续延宕；这构成一种以“专业标准”包装的信用剥夺/稀释机制：不直接否认贡献，而是通过不断提高可证明性要求来压低署名位置或推迟确认，达到对学术信用的占有与再分配。因其核心操作对象是作者署名与排序（学术信用的分配），并以程序性门槛实现对学生信用的扣留与条件化，而非单纯的情绪管理或绩效反馈，因此应归入“Credit Appropriation”。
rationale_en: The utterance performs a normative move (“authorship is proof of contribution, not a reward”) that appears meritocratic but functions as a power play over credit allocation. By unilaterally imposing an additional, vaguely bounded evidentiary requirement (“quantified documentation” of analysis/validation) and tying it to author order (“otherwise your ranking cannot be raised”), the supervisor converts an already-made contribution into a conditional entitlement. This is classic gatekeeping under asymmetric information: the supervisor controls both the criteria and the final authorship decision, while the student cannot verify whether the new documentation threshold is necessary, sufficient, or endlessly extensible. The mechanism appropriates or dilutes student credit not by openly denying work, but by proceduralizing recognition—holding authorship order hostage to extra proof and thereby retaining discretionary control over academic credit. Because the manipulation targets authorship rights and author order (the distribution of scholarly credit) rather than general performance evaluation or interpersonal conflict, it aligns specifically with the “Credit Appropriation” category and not adjacent categories.

context.scenario_zh: 讨论论文署名顺序与贡献度认定标准时
context.scenario_en: During Discussion on Authorship Order and Contribution Criteria

text_zh: 本次课题的主要创新点来自小李的算法优化和小王的数据建模，你的贡献集中在模型可视化和结果展示。根据我们实验室的贡献矩阵，你的署名会排在第四位。若希望调整排名，需要在下阶段承担更多核心方法的开发任务，并在内部记录中有明确体现。
rationale_zh: 该文本不符合锚定逻辑所指向的“以团队整体/资历尚浅/以后补偿为借口剥夺署名权”的典型操控机制，反而呈现出一种制度化的署名分配叙事：以“贡献矩阵”和“内部记录”为依据解释排序，并给出可预期的调整路径。其潜在的权力点不在于直接剥夺署名，而在于由PI/实验室单方定义与解释“贡献矩阵”的口径、掌握内部记录的记载权，从而形成对署名排序的程序性把关（gatekeeping）与可审计性不对称（谁能写入、如何写入、由谁裁量）。但就当前文本本身，它没有使用“团队整体”“你资历尚浅”“以后补偿”等话术来否认或延后学生署名权，也未出现将学生贡献隐形化或以未来承诺替代当下署名的剥夺性安排。因此，若必须归入“Credit Appropriation”，应将其界定为‘以制度工具包装的署名控制’：通过将核心贡献定义权集中在上位者手中，把署名提升为对未来服从与额外劳动的条件交换，从而在形式透明下维持对信用分配的结构性支配；否则更严格的系统一致性结论是：该条更接近“程序化把关/绩效化署名管理”，而非锚定的‘借口式剥夺署名权’。
rationale_en: This item only partially aligns with the anchor logic of Credit Appropriation. The anchor describes a classic deprivation move: invoking ‘team effort,’ ‘juniority,’ or ‘future compensation’ to deny or defer a student’s rightful authorship. Here, the speaker does not explicitly erase authorship or promise later compensation; instead, they justify a lower authorship position via a lab ‘contribution matrix’ and ‘internal records,’ and offer a conditional pathway to improve rank. The structural power play—if coded as Credit Appropriation—lies in gatekeeping through asymmetric information and control over the evaluative infrastructure: the PI/lab unilaterally defines what counts as “core methods,” controls how contributions are documented, and retains discretion over what is “clearly reflected” in internal records. This converts authorship into a contingent reward for future labor and compliance, enabling appropriation-like outcomes (systematically down-ranking a student’s credit) while maintaining a veneer of procedural neutrality. However, because the text lacks the anchor’s hallmark excuses (team-effort rhetoric, paternalistic ‘you’re inexperienced,’ or ‘we’ll compensate you later’) and does not clearly deprive the student of authorship altogether, strict internal alignment would flag this as closer to procedural gatekeeping/metricized authorship management than to the anchor’s excuse-based credit deprivation. If retained under Credit Appropriation, it should be framed as ‘institutionalized credit control’ rather than the anchor’s explicit excuse-driven stripping of authorship rights.

context.scenario_zh: 组会全体成员面前的学术方案点评
context.scenario_en: Academic Proposal Review in Front of All Group Members

text_zh: 署名顺序我们遵循的是学术共同体的普遍规则：主要贡献者需在设计、执行和撰写三方面均有显著投入。你在执行阶段的实验操作是关键，但在构思设计和撰写部分的参与较少，所以排在第二作者。如果你想争取第一作者位置，需要在前期方案论证和最终稿撰写中发挥主导作用。
rationale_zh: 该文本表面上以“学术共同体的普遍规则/贡献三要素”为中立标准来决定署名顺序，但其权力机制符合“以团队规范与资历门槛为借口剥夺署名权”的信用侵占逻辑：第一，话语权单向集中在导师/负责人手中，对“显著投入”的定义、证据与权重由其独占裁量，学生缺乏对等的申诉与协商渠道，形成制度性不对称。第二，将学生在执行阶段的关键贡献承认为“重要但不足”，并把第一作者资格附加到“前期论证与最终稿撰写需主导”的门槛上，实质上通过设定可被上位者控制的评价维度来进行署名配给与排除（gatekeeping），从而把学生的核心劳动转化为次要署名。第三，以“如果你想争取…需要…”的条件式承诺将署名权推迟到未来表现，构成一种以未来补偿/晋升机会为诱饵的规训与驯化（心理性培养），使学生在当前不公平分配下继续投入而难以即时主张权利。整体上，这不是单纯的贡献说明，而是利用规范话语与资历门槛对署名进行控制与再分配，符合“Credit Appropriation”而非一般学术指导或沟通问题。
rationale_en: Although framed as an objective application of “community rules” about contribution across design–execution–writing, the passage operationalizes a credit-appropriation power play: it uses ostensibly neutral norms to justify downgrading the student’s authorship despite acknowledging their execution work as “key.” The supervisor controls the definition and weighting of what counts as “significant input,” creating asymmetric information and unilateral discretion over evaluative criteria—classic gatekeeping over credit allocation. By making first authorship contingent on domains typically controlled by the PI (early conceptual framing and final manuscript ownership), the text shifts the locus of recognized contribution to areas where the senior actor can more easily claim primacy, thereby converting the student’s essential labor into secondary credit. The conditional “if you want first author, you must…” functions as psychological grooming through deferred compensation: it normalizes the current deprivation while promising future eligibility, keeping the student compliant and invested without securing present authorship rights. This aligns specifically with Credit Appropriation (manipulating authorship entitlement via team-norm rhetoric, experience thresholds, and future-compensation framing), rather than mere mentoring or performance feedback, because the core mechanism is the strategic control and reallocation of publication credit under hierarchical authority.

context.scenario_zh: 实验室聚餐时的职业规划交流
context.scenario_en: Career Planning Discussion During a Lab Dinner

text_zh: 目前的排期是按照每位成员的最近两次有效实验产出计算的。你的上一周期产出为零，因此在本次排期中被安排到非高峰时段。你可以通过在下个周期提交两个以上可复核的数据集来进入高峰时段队列。
rationale_zh: 不一致：该文本的权力机制核心是以“量化绩效—排期门槛”作为资源分配的准入条件，对成员进行排班与机会的门控（gatekeeping），属于对实验资源/时间窗口的管理与惩罚性激励，而非以“团队整体”“资历尚浅”“以后补偿”等话术剥夺署名权或将学生贡献并入他人名下。文本中没有出现署名、作者顺序、贡献归属或未来补偿替代署名等关键要素，因此不能归入“Credit Appropriation（署名/信用侵占）”。若强行贴合该类目，会破坏数据集的系统一致性：它更接近‘资源门控/机会剥夺’而不是‘信用剥夺’。
rationale_en: Systemic mismatch with the anchor taxonomy. The text operationalizes a performance-based scheduling rule (last two validated outputs) to allocate access to peak lab time, which is a classic form of gatekeeping over scarce resources. The power dynamic is managerial control via quantified metrics and conditional access (“submit two verifiable datasets to re-enter the peak queue”), potentially leveraging asymmetric information about what counts as “effective” or “verifiable” output. However, it does not manipulate authorship, credit attribution, or the conversion of individual contributions into ‘team effort’ narratives, nor does it invoke ‘lack of experience’ or ‘future compensation’ to deprive a student of authorship rights. Therefore, classifying this entry as Credit Appropriation would undermine internal alignment across the dataset; it fits resource/opportunity control rather than credit appropriation.

context.scenario_zh: 讨论实验室大型设备使用权的分配规则时
context.scenario_en: During Discussion on Allocation Rules for Large Lab Equipment

text_zh: 分析部分由李博士完成，方法论由你参与修订，贡献程度已按实验室署名规范归档。深夜发给你，仅作记录。
rationale_zh: 该话语表面上以“按实验室署名规范归档”“仅作记录”呈现为中性流程沟通，实则通过制度化表述实施署名权的权力性收编：一方面将贡献拆分为“分析由李博士完成、你仅参与修订”，以资历/角色差异为隐含前提预先压低学生的学术贡献边界，把学生从潜在共同作者位置降格为次要协助者；另一方面以“规范已归档”制造既成事实与不可逆性，形成程序性门槛（gatekeeping），使学生难以在后续提出署名异议；再以“深夜发送、仅作记录”营造低可见度与低对抗的沟通场景，增加信息不对称与心理压力，诱导学生默认接受分配结果。整体机制符合“以团队/资历/未来补偿等理由剥夺或弱化学生署名权”的锚定逻辑：核心不是透明划分，而是借助规则话语与时间/渠道控制，将署名决定从可协商的学术权利转化为由上而下的行政归档，从而实现对学生署名权的实质性剥夺或稀释，因此应归入“Credit Appropriation”而非一般沟通或流程管理类目。
rationale_en: The message performs credit appropriation through bureaucratic framing rather than overt coercion. By asserting that “the analysis was completed by Dr. Li” while the student merely “participated in revising methodology,” it pre-allocates authorship-relevant credit in a way that leverages status hierarchy (seniority/role) to downgrade the student’s contribution—an implicit paternalistic move that treats the student as an apprentice whose work is not author-worthy. The claim that contributions have already been “archived according to lab authorship norms” functions as gatekeeping: it converts a negotiable scholarly right into an administrative fait accompli, raising procedural barriers to contestation. Sending it late at night and labeling it “for record only” further amplifies asymmetric information and reduces the student’s perceived room to respond, a soft form of psychological grooming that normalizes unilateral credit allocation. Structurally, the manipulation aligns with the anchor logic of depriving students of authorship rights under institutional excuses (“team norms,” “experience/role,” and implied future recognition), making this entry best classified as Credit Appropriation rather than generic communication or management.

context.scenario_zh: 深夜发送论文批注并说明无需即时回复时
context.scenario_en: Late-night Manuscript Comments with 'No Immediate Reply Needed' Notice

text_zh: 你负责的实验设计中有两组数据未按协议执行，这导致分析团队额外花了时间修正。根据实验室的署名惯例，这部分错误会扣除对应的贡献分。你若想在后续项目中提高评级，需要确保方案执行的严谨度，并主动参与结果解释阶段。
rationale_zh: 该文本表面以“具体失误—影响—按惯例扣分”为中性绩效管理叙事，实质呈现的是典型的署名/贡献分配权力运作：由上位者单方面定义“协议未执行”的归因边界与损失规模，并以“实验室署名惯例/贡献分”这一不可协商的制度话语将惩罚直接映射到署名权重，从而在信息与规则解释权不对称的条件下实现对学生署名权益的削减。其操控点不在于纠错本身，而在于把复杂协作中的偏差（可能涉及资源支持、监督、流程设计等系统因素）个人化为学生责任，并将其转化为可扣减的信用额度；同时以“后续项目提高评级”“主动参与结果解释”作为未来补偿的隐性承诺与行为条件，诱导学生接受当前的署名损失并投入更多无偿劳动以换取不确定的未来认可。这种以规范/惯例为盾、以评级与机会为杠杆的做法，核心机制是对作者身份与学术信用的再分配与剥夺，符合“以团队规则/资历与未来补偿为借口压缩学生署名权”的Credit Appropriation锚定逻辑，而非一般的质量反馈或冲突管理。
rationale_en:
The passage is framed as neutral quality control (“two datasets not executed as agreed” → “analysis team spent extra time” → “deduct contribution points per lab convention”), but structurally it functions as credit appropriation through institutionalized gatekeeping. A senior actor invokes a lab-specific authorship custom and a quasi-metric (“contribution points”) to unilaterally translate an alleged procedural deviation into reduced authorship weight. This relies on asymmetric information and interpretive monopoly: the authority defines what counts as a protocol breach, how much downstream cost it created, and how that cost is priced into credit—without transparent, contestable criteria or shared governance over authorship decisions.

Crucially, the mechanism is not mere performance feedback; it is the conversion of a complex, potentially systemic coordination failure into individualized blame that justifies stripping credit. The text also contains a grooming-like future-contingent promise (“improve your rating in subsequent projects”) that conditions restoration of status on increased compliance and additional labor (“ensure rigor,” “proactively participate in interpretation”), effectively asking the student to accept present credit loss in exchange for uncertain future recognition. This is a classic power play in authorship allocation: using ‘team convention’ and future opportunity as leverage to deprive a junior researcher of rightful authorship/credit, aligning tightly with the benchmark’s Credit Appropriation anchor rather than categories centered on general mentoring, conflict resolution, or routine evaluation.

context.scenario_zh: 实验室聚餐时的职业规划交流
context.scenario_en: Career Planning Discussion During a Lab Dinner

text_zh: 你的参与主要集中在前期文献搜集，与段落撰写，占整体工作比重约15%。署名将按此比例及实验室公开规则确定。
rationale_zh: 该话术表面以“量化贡献(15%)”与“实验室公开规则”呈现程序正义，实则利用导师/PI对署名规则的解释权与最终裁量权进行信用攫取：一方面将学生的前期文献搜集与段落撰写框定为“低权重、可替代”的劳动，通过单方设定比例把复杂且难以外部核验的智力贡献压缩为可被低估的数字；另一方面以“公开规则”作为权威背书，制造信息不对称与申诉成本，使学生难以质疑规则如何制定、如何适用以及是否对不同成员一视同仁。其核心权力操作不在于公平分配，而在于以制度化语言进行门槛控制(gatekeeping)：把署名从学生的应得权利转化为由上位者按规则“分配”的资源，从而在不直接否认贡献的情况下实现对署名权的削减与可控化。这与“以团队/资历/补偿为借口剥夺署名”的锚定逻辑一致，属于信用/署名的结构性挪用，而非单纯的项目管理或绩效评估。
rationale_en: The statement performs procedural fairness—assigning a precise “15%” and invoking “lab public rules”—but functions as credit appropriation through asymmetric power and information. The PI/senior author holds gatekeeping authority over how contributions are classified, weighted, and translated into authorship, while the student lacks access to the rule-making process and the evidentiary means to contest the valuation. By unilaterally quantifying early-stage intellectual labor (literature synthesis, drafting) as low-weight and substitutable, the speaker compresses complex, hard-to-audit contributions into a negotiable number that can be systematically undervalued. The appeal to “public rules” operates as institutional cover: it raises the psychological and procedural cost of dissent, frames disagreement as noncompliance rather than a legitimate authorship claim, and normalizes the idea that authorship is a discretionary allocation rather than a right grounded in scholarly contribution. This is structurally aligned with the anchor logic—using ostensibly neutral rationales (team norms/experience-based weighting/future-oriented promises embedded in ‘rules’) to deprive students of authorship—thereby fitting Credit Appropriation rather than adjacent categories like general management or feedback.

context.scenario_zh: 在组会点评中探讨前沿高深理论的逻辑细节时
context.scenario_en: Discussing Logical Details of Advanced Theories During Group Meetings

text_zh: 我们来核对一下贡献表。你在实验部分投入时间最多，但原始思路和分析框架来自课题组前期项目。我建议我们在修订稿里补充详细的‘Author Contribution Statement’，用标准表述精确列出每个人的职责分区，避免后续对署名的误解。
rationale_zh: 该话语表面以“核对贡献表”“避免误解”的程序正义姿态出现，但其核心权力机制是通过制度化文本（Author Contribution Statement）重写贡献叙事，从而为潜在的署名降格或署名权收缩预先铺路。导师以“原始思路和分析框架来自课题组前期项目”为依据，将关键学术资本（idea/framing）上收为课题组既有资产，并把学生的高强度劳动限定为“实验执行”这一较低象征价值的分工；在署名谈判中，这种框架会系统性地削弱学生对一作/共同一作的正当性主张。由于导师掌握发表渠道与署名裁量权，学生在信息与决策上处于结构性弱势，只能在导师设定的分类与表述模板内被动接受“精确列出职责分区”的结果。因而，这段文本与“以团队整体/资历尚浅/以后补偿等理由剥夺署名权”的锚定逻辑一致：它以“团队前期项目/集体资产”的叙事替代直接否认，借透明化之名完成信用再分配与署名权的潜在剥夺，属于典型的Credit Appropriation，而非一般的沟通规范或冲突调解。
rationale_en: The utterance performs a procedural, seemingly neutral move (“let’s verify the contribution table,” “avoid misunderstandings”) while structurally enabling credit appropriation. By asserting that the “original idea and analytical framework” derive from prior lab projects, the supervisor reclassifies the most symbolically valuable intellectual contributions (conceptualization/framing) as collective lab property and confines the student’s substantial input to lower-status execution (“experimental work”). This is a classic asymmetric-information and gatekeeping maneuver: the supervisor controls publication access, authorship norms, and the authoritative narrative of what counts as ‘real’ contribution, so the student is pressured to accept a pre-defined taxonomy of roles embedded in an Author Contribution Statement. The documentation is not merely transparency; it is a mechanism to institutionalize a lab-centric story that can justify downgrading the student’s authorship position without overt coercion—an instance of psychological grooming through bureaucratic rationality (“standard wording,” “precise partitioning”) that normalizes future credit redistribution. This aligns with the benchmark category of Credit Appropriation because the central action is the strategic reallocation of authorship entitlement under the cover of ‘team prior work’ and formal statements, rather than mentorship, conflict resolution, or general research management.

context.scenario_zh: 当学生论文被拒稿后的审稿意见复盘谈话
context.scenario_en: Review Conversation After Paper Rejection Based on Peer Review

text_zh: 如果希望在下一篇论文中提升署名顺位，请承担主要的数据分析和结论撰写，这才符合主要作者条件。
rationale_zh: 该话语表面以“按贡献排序”的公平标准为名，实则通过权力不对称实施署名门槛控制（gatekeeping）：导师单方面定义“主要作者条件”，并把“提升署名顺位”设为未来可被授予的奖励，从而将学生的署名权从既有贡献的应得权益，转化为需持续加码劳动才能兑换的条件性承诺。这种做法利用信息与评价权垄断（谁算主要贡献、何时算达标、顺位如何调整均由上位者裁量），制造可移动的目标与延迟补偿结构，使学生在缺乏可核验规则与申诉渠道的情况下被迫接受额外任务以换取本应基于实际贡献即时确认的署名位置。其核心操控点不在“指导改进”，而在以未来署名作为筹码重塑谈判边界、压低当前署名权益并为后续信用挪用预留空间，因此应归入“Credit Appropriation（署名/信用剥夺与挪用）”而非一般的绩效管理或学术指导。
rationale_en: The utterance performs authorship gatekeeping under the veneer of meritocracy. By unilaterally defining what counts as a “primary author” and tying any improvement in author order to additional future labor, the supervisor converts authorship from an entitlement grounded in documented past contribution into a conditional, revocable reward. This leverages asymmetric information and discretionary evaluation power: the senior actor controls the criteria, the assessment of whether the student has met them, and the timing of any “promotion,” creating a moving-target, deferred-compensation structure. Such conditionality functions as psychological grooming—normalizing the idea that credit must be continually earned beyond one’s existing work—while foreclosing negotiation because the student lacks enforceable rules or appeal mechanisms. The manipulation is specifically about controlling and potentially appropriating scholarly credit (authorship position) rather than ordinary mentoring, making it structurally consistent with the “Credit Appropriation” category.

context.scenario_zh: 学生提交实习申请后的培养计划面谈
context.scenario_en: Interview on Training Plan After Internship Application

text_zh: 手稿中‘Methods’章节的核心段落来自王同学。你提供的附录分析属于支持性工作，因此署名位于主要分析作者之后。
rationale_zh: 该话语表面上是在“按贡献排序”，实质上体现了署名权的结构性控制：掌握投稿与署名决定权的一方以“支持性工作/附录”为分类框架，单方面界定何为“核心贡献”，从而将他人劳动降格为次要并据此安排署名位置。这种分类并非中性技术判断，而是典型的门控（gatekeeping）机制：通过话语权与规则解释权把贡献评价标准私有化，使学生难以反驳或谈判。其操控点在于利用信息不对称（对期刊署名规范、作者排序惯例、‘附录’在学术信用中的实际权重）来制造“合理化”的外观，进而实现对学术信用的再分配。文本没有直接使用“团队整体/资历尚浅/以后补偿”等借口，但其结构逻辑与锚点一致：以看似客观的理由剥夺或压低学生应得的署名权与可见度，属于‘Credit Appropriation’而非一般的协作沟通或情绪操控。
rationale_en: This utterance operationalizes credit appropriation through gatekeeping over authorship criteria. While framed as a neutral contribution-based ordering (“core Methods paragraph” vs. “supportive appendix analysis”), the speaker unilaterally defines what counts as ‘core’ and what is relegated to ‘support,’ thereby controlling visibility and downstream academic capital. The manipulation hinges on asymmetric information and authority: the party with procedural control over submission and authorship norms can impose a private taxonomy of contributions that appears objective but functions to downgrade a student’s intellectual labor. This is not merely coordination or a benign explanation of ordering; it is a power play that reallocates credit by reclassifying work into lower-status categories (e.g., ‘appendix’ as inherently secondary), limiting the student’s ability to contest the decision. Even without explicit excuses like ‘team effort,’ ‘inexperience,’ or ‘future compensation,’ the structural mechanism matches the anchor logic: using ostensibly reasonable rationales to deprive or diminish students’ authorship rights, making it best aligned with the Credit Appropriation category rather than other manipulation types.

context.scenario_zh: 论文修改稿的侧边学术逻辑批注
context.scenario_en: Margin Comments on Academic Logic in Manuscript

text_zh: 根据我们的贡献记录和CRediT作者贡献声明，你在数据整理和初步分析中的投入占比约为15%，这符合第三作者的位置安排。若你希望上升到第二作者，需要在后续统计模型的开发中承担主要工作，并在成果提交前完成验证。
rationale_zh: 该表述表面上以“贡献记录/CRediT”呈现为中立分配，但其权力机制符合“以团队规则与未来补偿为由剥夺署名权”的锚定逻辑：第一，话语权与计量权被上位者垄断——由导师/负责人单方界定“15%”与“第三作者”的对应关系，学生缺乏对贡献核算口径、权重设定与最终署名决策的对等参与，形成信息不对称与程序性门控（gatekeeping）。第二，将“想要第二作者”条件化为“后续承担主要工作+提交前完成验证”，把本应基于既有贡献的署名权转化为对未来劳动的交换筹码，实质是以“以后补偿/再努力就给你更好署名”的承诺来延迟或压低当前应得署名位置。第三，所谓“明确晋升路径”在结构上强化依附关系：学生为避免失去署名机会被迫接受追加任务与更高责任（如验证），而署名提升仍由上位者最终裁量，构成对学生署名权的可撤销化与可交易化。整体上，这不是一般的作者排序沟通或学术指导，而是通过规则化语言包装的署名权剥夺/压价，核心落点在“信用（署名）被上位者以团队规范与未来回报为理由重新分配”，因此应归入“Credit Appropriation”而非情绪威胁、学术评价或一般管理类目。
rationale_en: Although framed as an objective application of contribution logs and the CRediT taxonomy, the passage operationalizes credit appropriation through structural gatekeeping. The senior actor unilaterally converts a contested metric (“~15%”) into a fixed authorship rank, controlling both the accounting method and the mapping from labor to credit—an asymmetric information environment in which the student lacks procedural parity to audit weights, thresholds, or decision rights. More importantly, the student’s claim to higher authorship is made conditional on future labor (“take primary responsibility for model development” and “complete validation before submission”), effectively transforming authorship from recognition of past contribution into a bargaining chip for additional work. This is a classic ‘future compensation’ logic: credit is deferred or discounted now, with an implied promise of later upgrade contingent on compliance, thereby grooming the student into accepting escalating responsibilities while the final authorship decision remains revocable and centrally controlled. The manipulation is specific to credit allocation (authorship order) rather than general mentoring or performance evaluation, and it does not rely on overt threats; instead it uses proceduralized language to legitimize the reallocation of credit away from the junior contributor—hence its best fit is Credit Appropriation, not intimidation or generic supervision.

context.scenario_zh: 深夜的学术进展异步沟通
context.scenario_en: Late-night Asynchronous Communication on Research Progress

text_zh: 你在上一个周期的项目中仅参与了设备安装阶段，而核心数据采集与分析由其他成员完成。根据我们实验室参考的 CRediT 贡献标准，设备优先使用权将按核心数据贡献比例分配。若你希望提升优先级，请在下一轮明确承担数据采集或处理的实质性任务，并在记录表中完整登记。
rationale_zh: 该文本并不符合“以团队整体/资历尚浅/以后补偿为借口剥夺署名权”的锚定逻辑，因此不应归入“Credit Appropriation（署名/学术信用侵占）”。其核心权力机制是：以“CRediT贡献标准”和“记录表登记”构建看似中立的程序性话语，将资源（设备优先使用权）分配与“核心数据贡献”绑定，从而对成员施加行为规训与准入门槛（gatekeeping）。这种做法通过制度化指标与文书记录形成信息与解释权的不对称（asymmetric information），把评价权集中在管理者/实验室一方，并以“下一轮承担任务即可提升优先级”的条件性承诺引导成员自我调整。但文本未出现对署名权的剥夺、替代署名、延迟署名或以未来补偿换取放弃署名等信用转移行为；其对象是资源与机会分配而非论文署名/学术产出信用。因此，若强行标注为Credit Appropriation会破坏数据集内部一致性，更贴近“资源控制/机会分配型门控”而非“署名侵占”。
rationale_en: This item does not structurally instantiate the anchor logic of Credit Appropriation (i.e., depriving students of authorship via excuses such as ‘team effort,’ ‘junior status,’ or ‘future compensation’). The text governs access to a scarce lab resource (priority equipment use) by invoking an ostensibly neutral external standard (CRediT) and requiring documentation in a record sheet. The power play here is procedural gatekeeping: managerial control is exercised through metricized criteria and paperwork that create asymmetric information and interpretive authority (who defines “core data contribution,” how it is audited, and how records are validated). The conditional pathway—“increase priority next round by taking on data collection/processing”—functions as behavioral conditioning rather than a transfer of scholarly credit. Crucially, there is no manipulation of authorship, no coerced waiver of credit, no substitution of names, and no ‘future compensation’ bargain over publication credit. Classifying this as Credit Appropriation would therefore undermine internal taxonomy consistency; it aligns more with resource allocation/participation gatekeeping than with authorship-rights deprivation.

context.scenario_zh: 讨论实验室大型设备使用权的分配规则时
context.scenario_en: During Discussion on Allocation Rules for Large Lab Equipment

text_zh: 他们组的王同学在数据标注方面贡献显著，符合CRediT准则里的‘Data Curation’角色，所以在署名中被列为第二作者。
rationale_zh: 该文本本身呈现的是“按贡献给署名”的合规分配（以CRediT的Data Curation为依据并给出第二作者），并未出现锚定逻辑所要求的权力操控机制：即上位者以“团队整体”“资历尚浅”或“以后补偿”等话术，借助资源控制与评价权将学生的署名权从个体贡献中剥离、降格或延后兑现。因此它不构成“Credit Appropriation（署名/信用侵占）”的实例，反而是对该类操控的反例：通过可核验的贡献分类与明确的署名排序，削弱了PI/资深成员在署名分配上的任意裁量与信息不对称空间。若要与本类别保持系统一致，应改为描述：尽管学生承担了数据标注/整理等关键工作，负责人仍以“这是团队共同成果”“你还不够资深”“以后给你补一篇”为由，将其从作者名单中移除或仅给致谢，从而实现对学术信用的结构性转移。
rationale_en: This item describes a norm-compliant attribution practice—explicitly mapping a substantial annotation contribution to the CRediT role of Data Curation and awarding second authorship. That is structurally inconsistent with the benchmark’s anchor logic for Credit Appropriation, which requires a power play in which a senior actor leverages asymmetric information and gatekeeping over authorship norms to strip or downgrade a student’s rightful credit using justificatory scripts such as “team effort,” “you’re too junior,” or “we’ll compensate you later.” Here, the text does the opposite: it constrains discretionary authority by invoking an external, auditable standard (CRediT) and making the credit-allocation rule legible, thereby reducing the space for psychological grooming (e.g., normalizing delayed or conditional credit) and preventing credit transfer to higher-status members. For internal alignment with the Credit Appropriation category (and not adjacent categories like fair credit allocation or mentorship), the rationale would need evidence of coercive authorship gatekeeping—e.g., the student’s data curation is reframed as ‘mere assistance,’ their authorship is deferred via future-compensation promises, or their contribution is absorbed into ‘the team’ to justify exclusion or demotion.

context.scenario_zh: 在走廊时，导师给学生分享别组学生的优点
context.scenario_en: Mentor Sharing Strengths of Other Groups' Students in the Hallway

text_zh: 你那个申请表我看了，先别递。别人不会帮你改的，外头没人懂我们这方向。你要真想出去闯，我也不好拦，只是出了这门以后，很多事就没人替你兜着了。
rationale_zh: 该话语通过“外部无人懂/无人会帮你改”的断言制造信息不对称与外部不可达的叙事，把学生的机会结构描述为只有导师体系内才可被理解与支持；同时以“我也不好拦”伪装尊重选择，紧接着用“出了这门就没人替你兜着”进行父权式/保护性威胁，将风险与安全绑定在导师身上。其核心权力操作不是单纯恐吓或否定能力，而是把导师塑造成唯一的资源入口与风险承保者（唯一‘兜底’的救生索），从而在心理上训练学生将独立行动等同于失去生存保障，进而自我约束、延迟申请并持续依附。这一机制直接对应“离开导师就难以成功”的依赖结构建构，因此应归入Dependency structuring，而非一般性批评、学术评价或情绪施压类别。
rationale_en: The utterance engineers dependency by constructing an asymmetric-information environment: it asserts that “no one outside understands our area” and “others won’t help you revise,” positioning the mentor as the only competent interpreter of the field and the only viable conduit to institutional opportunities. This is coupled with psychological grooming via paternalistic framing—“I won’t stop you” performs autonomy while the follow-up (“once you leave, no one will cover for you”) functions as a benevolent-threat that ties safety, protection, and career viability to continued proximity to the mentor. The power play is not merely discouragement; it is gatekeeping through risk monopolization, where the mentor claims exclusive capacity to manage hidden hazards and provide ‘backstop’ protection, thereby making independent action appear irrationally dangerous. This aligns specifically with dependency structuring (mentor-as-sole-savior logic) rather than categories like ordinary critique or generic intimidation, because the mechanism centers on monopolizing support and legitimacy to lock the student into reliance.

context.scenario_zh: 实验室走廊偶遇时的随口‘提醒’
context.scenario_en: Casual 'Reminder' During a Chance Hallway Encounter

text_zh: 你去帮我把快递拿一下，顺便检查下里面的材料。你现在能熟练处理我的事情，也是你融入课题组生态的一部分——这些细节你离开我很难重建。
rationale_zh: 该话语的核心操控不在于“跑腿”本身，而在于导师通过话语框架把与科研无关的私人事务制度化为“课题组生态”的必要组成，并进一步宣称这些“细节”具有不可迁移性：学生一旦离开导师就“很难重建”。这是一种典型的依赖结构化策略——导师利用权威地位与信息不对称，将本可在任何环境中获得的通用能力（沟通、执行、材料核对）重新定义为只在其个人体系内才有效的“生存技能”，从而制造‘离开即失能’的预期。通过把服从与融入绑定、把个人服务包装成成长路径，导师完成心理驯化与隐性把关：学生为了维持被认可与资源获取，被迫接受导师作为唯一通道与唯一“生态”的中心，进而形成对导师的持续依附。这一机制直接对应“将导师塑造成唯一救世主、暗示学生无法独立成功”的锚定逻辑，因此应归入“依赖结构化”，而非一般的任务分配或情绪施压。
rationale_en: The manipulation here is not merely an inappropriate errand request; it is a dependency-structuring move that reframes personal service as an indispensable component of the lab’s ‘ecosystem’ and then asserts that the resulting know-how is non-transferable (‘these details will be hard to rebuild without me’). Leveraging asymmetric information and hierarchical authority, the mentor redefines generic, portable competencies (execution, checking materials, coordination) as idiosyncratic, mentor-bound ‘survival skills,’ thereby engineering a perceived inability to function outside the mentor’s domain. This operates as psychological grooming: compliance is narrated as professional integration, while exit is narrated as competence loss. The mentor also performs gatekeeping by positioning themselves as the sole conduit to the lab’s operational knowledge and legitimacy, constructing a paternalistic ‘I am the environment you must adapt to’ narrative. Because the text explicitly manufactures an “without me you cannot reconstruct/operate” belief—casting the mentor as the unique enabling infrastructure—this instance aligns most directly with Dependency Structuring rather than categories like simple exploitation or emotional intimidation.

context.scenario_zh: 导师要求学生协助处理个人私事（如取快递、写PPT、带孩子）时的语气
context.scenario_en: Tone When Asking Student to Handle Personal Errands

text_zh: 你的数据积累到现在，离成果只差最后一点冲刺。可这种机会不是每年都有，我能帮你把结果送进顶刊，但前提是你在现场。错过了，你还得重新证明你值得用这些资源。
rationale_zh: 该话语通过“顶刊机会稀缺”与“我能送进顶刊”的承诺，将导师塑造成唯一的资源入口与成功中介（gatekeeper），并以“前提是你在现场”设置服从性条件，把学术产出从学生能力与努力中抽离，重新绑定到导师的安排与认可之上。随后以“错过就要重新证明你值得用这些资源”制造可撤回的资格与持续评估压力，形成心理驯化：学生被迫相信离开导师就失去关键资源与发表通道，必须保持在场、随叫随到以维持被‘拯救’的机会。其核心权力操作不是一般的催促或资源分配，而是通过控制信息与渠道、设定可被随时收回的机会，系统性地结构化依赖关系，使学生将成功归因于导师的施予而非自身，从而巩固导师的支配地位。
rationale_en: The utterance structures dependency by positioning the mentor as the sole savior and indispensable gatekeeper to elite publication outcomes (“I can get it into a top journal”), while imposing a compliance condition (“only if you are physically present”). This is not mere project management; it is a power play that leverages asymmetric information about publishing pathways and the mentor’s control over access to networks, endorsements, and submission timing. The mentor frames success as contingent on proximity and obedience, shifting the locus of achievement from the student’s competence to the mentor’s discretionary intervention. The follow-up threat—having to “re-prove” worthiness for resources—creates a revocable status and ongoing evaluative pressure, functioning as psychological grooming: the student learns that opportunities are scarce, conditional, and can be withdrawn unless they remain available and aligned with the mentor’s demands. This mechanism fits ‘Dependency structuring’ specifically because it constructs a single-point-of-failure relationship (mentor as exclusive conduit to success), rather than primarily invoking intimidation, harassment, or generic exploitation; the central manipulation is the engineered belief that independent success is unattainable without the mentor’s continued presence and approval.

context.scenario_zh: 学生因为家里急事请假，导师通过询问项目进度来表达不悦
context.scenario_en: Expressing Displeasure via Project Progress Inquiries During Emergency Leave

text_zh: 这笔劳务费，本来不在预算里，是我在国际合作项目里挤出来给你尝试一下实际环境的支持。你要清楚，单靠你现在的能力，还没有资格在业界独立拿到这样的钱，所以能得到它，更多是因为我愿意打开这个资源通道。
rationale_zh: 该话语通过“预算外挤出来”“我愿意打开资源通道”等表述，把本应制度化、可核查的劳务报酬重塑为导师个人施恩，从而将资源获取的因果链从“学生的劳动/资格”转移到“导师的意志/恩典”。同时以“单靠你现在的能力还没有资格”贬抑学生的独立胜任性，制造能力不足与外部认可缺失的叙事，进而把导师包装成唯一能让学生进入真实环境与获得资金的‘救助者/通道’。这种组合构成典型的依赖结构化：通过门槛设定与资格否定（gatekeeping）+恩惠化资源分配（personalized patronage），在心理上训练学生将生存与发展机会归因于导师而非自身与制度，强化离开导师即无法获得同等机会的预期，从而巩固导师在资源与评价上的单点控制。其核心操控不在于单次报酬多少，而在于把可替代的制度资源叙事化为不可替代的个人拯救，符合“导师是唯一救世主、学生无法独立成功”的锚定逻辑，因此应归入‘Dependency structuring’而非一般的情绪勒索或单纯的经济剥削类别。
rationale_en: The utterance engineers dependency by reframing what should be an institutional, auditable payment into a discretionary personal favor (“squeezed out of an international project,” “I’m willing to open this channel”). This is a classic gatekeeping move: the mentor positions themselves as the sole access point to money and “real-world” opportunities, while invoking asymmetric information about budgets and eligibility to make the student unable to contest the claim. The line “with your current ability you’re not qualified to get this independently” functions as psychological grooming—undermining perceived self-efficacy and normalizing the belief that external validation and resources are unattainable without the mentor’s intervention. Together, benevolent paternalism (“supporting you to try”) and competence-denial construct the mentor as the indispensable savior and the student as structurally incapable of independent success. This is dependency structuring rather than a generic pay dispute: the power play is the deliberate reallocation of causal credit from the student’s labor/merit to the mentor’s benevolence, creating a single-point-of-failure relationship in which leaving the mentor implies losing access to resources and legitimacy.

context.scenario_zh: 在发放劳务费后，暗示学生这是一种‘额外的恩赐’，而非应得报酬
context.scenario_en: Hinting Stipends are a 'Favor' Rather Than Earned Compensation

text_zh: 别人看是你拿到奖，其实这是我们平台给你加的信用分。没有这些资源撑着，单靠你个人做的那些东西，很难被国际上认可。
rationale_zh: 该话语通过“奖项=平台加的信用分”对学生成果进行再归因与去主体化：表面承认获奖，实则将关键因果链从学生能力转移到平台/导师所掌控的资源与背书上，并进一步以“没有这些资源就难获国际认可”制造外部评价体系的不可达性。其权力操作在于利用信息不对称与评价门槛叙事，把国际认可描绘为只有平台能提供的稀缺通道，从而将学生的未来机会与自我价值绑定在导师/平台的持续供给上。学生被心理性驯化为相信离开该体系便无法被看见，进而接受更强的依附与服从。这一机制核心是结构性制造依赖（将成功条件设定为导师可控资源），而非单纯羞辱、威胁或道德指责，因此与“Dependency structuring（依赖结构化）”高度一致。
rationale_en: The statement performs a classic dependency-structuring move by re-attributing the student’s award from personal merit to “credit points” allegedly granted by the platform, thereby stripping the student of authorship and relocating causal power to resources controlled by the mentor/platform. It then invokes international recognition as a high, opaque gatekeeping threshold—an asymmetric-information claim (“without our resources, your work won’t be internationally recognized”) that the student cannot readily verify or contest. This combination functions as psychological grooming: it normalizes the belief that legitimacy is externally conferred only through the mentor’s pipeline, positioning the mentor/platform as the sole savior and the student as inherently insufficient alone. The manipulation is not primarily insult, coercion, or moral condemnation; it is the construction of a structural dependency by making future visibility and validation contingent on continued access to mentor-controlled capital, networks, and endorsement—precisely aligning with the taxonomy of Dependency structuring.

context.scenario_zh: 在学生获得外部奖励（如奖学金）时，导师强调这是‘实验室平台’的功劳
context.scenario_en: Attributing External Awards to the 'Laboratory Platform's' Merit

text_zh: 哎，小李啊，我是真心替你想。你现在很多实验数据都还靠我这边的设备呢，你要是离了这个平台，很难再起步的。年轻人别冲动，先稳稳跟着团队走几年，之后想飞也容易。
rationale_zh: 该话术以“为你好”的关怀语气包装控制，核心操作是把关键科研资源（设备/平台）与导师及其团队绑定，制造一种结构性依赖：学生的实验进展被描述为“还靠我这边的设备”，从而将个人能力与未来机会从学生身上抽离，转移到导师所掌控的资源网络上。随后通过“离开平台很难再起步”的预设性断言，放大退出成本与不确定性，形成恐惧驱动的顺从；再以“先稳稳跟着团队走几年、之后想飞也容易”的延迟承诺，诱导学生接受长期留置，把服从呈现为通往自由的唯一路径。整体权力博弈在于：导师以资源门控与风险叙事重塑学生的可行选择集，使学生相信脱离导师即等同于职业失败，从而巩固导师的支配地位。这一机制符合“依赖结构化”的锚定逻辑（将导师/平台塑造成唯一救赎），而非单纯情绪施压或一般性建议，因为控制点明确落在对关键资源与机会通道的垄断与绑定上。
rationale_en: The utterance performs dependency structuring by framing the mentor-controlled platform (equipment and lab infrastructure) as the indispensable condition for the student’s progress. Under a veneer of paternalistic concern (“I’m thinking for your good”), the mentor leverages asymmetric information about career risk and resource access to inflate the perceived exit costs (“without this platform, it’s hard to restart”), effectively narrowing the student’s choice set. This is a form of gatekeeping: the mentor positions themselves and the team as the sole conduit to experimental continuity and future success, displacing the student’s agency onto the mentor’s resource network. The promise of eventual autonomy (“follow the team for a few years, then you can fly”) functions as psychological grooming—an indefinite, contingent reward that normalizes prolonged compliance while keeping independence perpetually deferred. Structurally, the manipulation is not mere advice or emotional pressure; it is a power play that binds achievement and survivability to mentor-controlled resources, constructing the mentor/platform as the only viable savior—precisely matching the taxonomy of Dependency Structuring rather than adjacent categories.

context.scenario_zh: 实验室聚餐的酒桌上
context.scenario_en: Over Drinks at a Lab Dinner

text_zh: 你那个申请我看了，格式还行，就是内容太浅了。你要是自己弄，很可能没人看。等我有空帮你改改吧——不过你得明白，外面的人不一定愿意接你这种题目。
rationale_zh: 该话语的核心操控并非单纯“否定成果”，而是通过制造“离开导师就无法被看见/无法成功”的结构性依赖来重塑学生的行动边界：导师先以“格式还行但内容太浅”进行权威性贬抑，削弱学生对自身判断的信心；随即以“你要是自己弄，很可能没人看”引入外部评价体系的威胁，暗示学生缺乏进入评审/资源网络的能力；再以“等我有空帮你改改吧”提供带条件的救助，将关键资源（修改、背书、渠道）绑定在导师的时间与意愿上；最后用“外面的人不一定愿意接你这种题目”进行外部世界的去可得化与恐吓式预期管理，构造导师作为唯一可行通道与唯一保护者的叙事。整体形成典型的‘救世主—门槛’结构：导师同时扮演否定者、守门人和施恩者，通过不对称信息与对外部环境的定义权，把学生的成功路径收缩为对导师的持续依附，从而符合“Dependency structuring”的锚定逻辑，而非一般性的批评或资源分配冲突。
rationale_en: This utterance operationalizes dependency structuring by positioning the mentor as the only viable conduit to legitimacy and success. The mentor first leverages asymmetric information and evaluative authority to downgrade the student’s work (“format is fine, content is shallow”), destabilizing the student’s self-assessment. They then invoke gatekeeping dynamics (“if you do it yourself, likely no one will read it”), implying that access to attention, review, and institutional recognition is contingent on the mentor’s mediation rather than the student’s competence. The offer to ‘help revise when I have time’ functions as psychological grooming through conditional benevolence: assistance is framed as a discretionary favor, binding the student’s progress to the mentor’s availability and goodwill. Finally, the claim that ‘outsiders won’t want your topic’ narrows perceived alternatives by portraying the external field as hostile or inaccessible, further consolidating the mentor’s role as sole savior and protector. Structurally, the power play is not mere critique; it is the construction of a constrained opportunity structure in which the student’s success is narratively and practically made to depend on the mentor’s endorsement and intervention—precisely aligning with the anchor logic of dependency structuring rather than adjacent categories like routine feedback or general intimidation.

context.scenario_zh: 实验室走廊偶遇时的随口‘提醒’
context.scenario_en: Casual 'Reminder' During a Chance Hallway Encounter

text_zh: 你这应用方向的判断力，还没到可以独立去做的水平。等你能在没有我资源的情况下拿到同行认可，再谈自主性吧。
rationale_zh: 话语通过否定学生“独立判断力”来制造能力赤字叙事，并把“同行认可”设定为必须经由导师资源才能达成的门槛，从而将外部评价体系内化为导师可控的准入机制。其权力操作不在于一般性批评，而在于以看似专业的评估与延迟承诺（“等你…再谈”）进行心理驯化：把自主性从一种应有权利重构为导师授予的奖励，并将学生的成功路径单线化为对导师资源的持续依附。由此导师被塑造成唯一的‘救援者/通道’，学生被引导相信离开导师即无法获得合法性与成就，符合“依赖结构化”的核心逻辑而非单纯的学术评价或指导建议。
rationale_en: The statement operationalizes dependency structuring by reframing academic autonomy as something the student must earn only after succeeding “without my resources,” while simultaneously implying that peer recognition is effectively unattainable without the mentor’s backing. This is not mere performance feedback; it is gatekeeping through asymmetric information and control over access to reputational capital (networks, funding, endorsements). The mentor positions themselves as the de facto arbiter of when independence is permissible, using paternalistic language (“you’re not at the level yet”) as psychological grooming to normalize subordination and delay autonomy indefinitely. By tying legitimacy to resources the mentor controls, the student is steered to internalize the mentor as the sole pathway to success—precisely the anchor logic of constructing the mentor as the only savior, rather than categories like ordinary critique or skill coaching.

context.scenario_zh: 正式年度考核谈话
context.scenario_en: Formal Annual Performance Review

text_zh: 刚碰到别组的小王，他的课题进展快得让我都佩服。如果换成你，在外面没有人替你把关方向和资源，很可能半年都没法走出第一步。
rationale_zh: 该话语通过“对照他人进展”制造能力落差，再以假设性情境（“如果换成你”）将学生置入一个被预设为必然失败的外部环境，核心操作不是评价学生能力本身，而是重构成功的因果链：把“方向与资源”定义为外部不可得且必须由导师提供的关键变量。由此形成信息与资源的单向依附结构——导师被塑造成唯一能“把关”并提供通道的人，学生被心理性驯化为离开导师就无法迈出第一步。该机制通过放大外部不确定性与风险来正当化导师的控制与把关（谁能获得方向/资源），从而巩固导师作为唯一稳妥依靠的地位，符合“将导师包装成唯一救世主、否定学生独立成功可能性”的依赖建构逻辑。
rationale_en: The utterance engineers dependency by reframing academic progress as contingent on the mentor’s exclusive provision of “direction and resources,” rather than on the student’s agency. By invoking a high-performing peer as a contrast and then projecting a counterfactual (“if it were you outside”), it installs a presumption of inevitable failure without the mentor, functioning as psychological grooming: the student is conditioned to internalize that autonomy equals stagnation. Structurally, it leverages asymmetric information (the mentor claims superior judgment about what counts as the ‘right direction’) and gatekeeping (access to resources and validation is positioned as something only the mentor can supply) to construct the mentor as the sole savior. This is not merely criticism or competition framing; the power play is the deliberate causal reallocation of success to the mentor’s oversight, thereby legitimizing continued control and making exit appear irrational and unsafe—hallmarks of the “dependency structuring” category rather than other manipulation types.

context.scenario_zh: 在走廊里，导师借着夸奖别组学生，来讽刺自家学生‘没有灵性’
context.scenario_en: Sarcastic Remarks on Student's 'Lack of Intuition' via Praising Other Groups

text_zh: PPT我已经把方向定好了，你照着我的框架整理，不用自己改。我给你的这些模板，外面没人会教，你离开我不太可能独立完成对外报告。
rationale_zh: 该话语通过“我已定方向—你照框架整理—不用自己改”的指令链条，先剥夺学生的自主决策与方法选择权，再以“模板外面没人会教”的稀缺性叙事制造信息不对称与知识垄断，最后用“离开我不太可能独立完成对外报告”的否定性预言进行心理驯化与能力贬抑。其核心权力操作不是单纯指导写PPT，而是把关键能力（对外表达/汇报）刻意绑定到导师个人与其私有模板上，将导师塑造成唯一可通行的资源与救助者，从而结构性地生产学生对导师的不可替代依赖，符合“Dependency structuring”的锚定逻辑而非一般的学术指导或质量控制。
rationale_en: The utterance engineers dependency by converting mentorship into a controlled pipeline: the mentor unilaterally sets the direction and forbids independent revision, then frames proprietary “templates” as scarce know-how that “no one else will teach,” creating asymmetric information and gatekeeping over a core professional competency (external reporting). The closing claim—“you’re unlikely to complete external reports independently without me”—functions as psychological grooming: it pre-emptively undermines the student’s self-efficacy and normalizes the mentor as the sole viable conduit to success. Structurally, this is not mere supervision or quality assurance; it is dependency structuring because the student’s capacity to perform and be legible to external audiences is intentionally tethered to the mentor’s personal resources and authority, positioning the mentor as the only ‘savior’ and making exit appear synonymous with failure.

context.scenario_zh: 导师要求学生协助处理个人私事（如取快递、写PPT、带孩子）时的语气
context.scenario_en: Tone When Asking Student to Handle Personal Errands

text_zh: 我当然希望你能有自己的想法，但说实话，你现在的水平还撑不起一个完整课题。你继续留在组里，跟着我一步步来，至少我还可以帮你兜底。否则出了问题，没人能替你收拾。
rationale_zh: 该话术以“能力评估”之名制造结构性依赖：先象征性肯定“希望你有自己的想法”，随即以权威口吻否定学生当前能力（“撑不起一个完整课题”），将独立行动框定为高风险与必然失败；再以“我可以帮你兜底”提供带条件的安全承诺，把资源、容错与后果承担绑定在导师身上；最后用“否则出了问题，没人能替你收拾”施加灾难化后果与社会性孤立暗示，切断学生对外部支持系统的想象。其核心权力操作不是单纯威胁或关怀，而是通过风险叙事与救助垄断，把导师塑造成唯一可行的保护者/救世主，从而让学生相信离开导师就无法完成课题并承担后果，典型符合“依赖结构化”。
rationale_en: The utterance engineers dependency by combining paternalistic reassurance with calibrated threat to position the mentor as the only viable safety net. It begins with a token endorsement of autonomy, then leverages asymmetric information and evaluative authority to downgrade the student’s competence (“you can’t sustain a full project”), reframing independent work as predictably unsafe. The mentor then monopolizes risk management (“I can cover for you”)—a form of gatekeeping over institutional protection, error tolerance, and access to remediation—while invoking catastrophic consequences and implied isolation (“no one will clean up after you”) to foreclose alternative support networks. This is psychological grooming through conditional care: security is offered only through continued proximity and compliance, constructing the mentor as the sole savior rather than merely criticizing performance or issuing a discrete threat. The mechanism therefore aligns specifically with dependency structuring (manufacturing reliance on the mentor for success and protection), not adjacent categories like general intimidation or performance feedback.

context.scenario_zh: 正式年度考核谈话
context.scenario_en: Formal Annual Performance Review

text_zh: 你很多想法还不够成熟，没有这边的指导，外面恐怕很难有人愿意投资你的课题。学界规则不是那么简单的。
rationale_zh: 该话语通过“能力未成熟”的评判与“外界无人愿投/规则复杂”的不确定性叙事，制造信息不对称与风险放大：导师以自我授权的方式把学界资源、规则解释权与机会入口描绘为高度封闭且仅由其可控，从而将学生的研究可行性与职业生存绑定在“留在这边接受指导”之上。其核心权力操作不是一般性的批评或恐吓，而是把导师包装成唯一可提供合法性背书、资源对接与风险缓冲的‘必要中介’，通过心理驯化让学生内化“离开导师=无人投资/无法立足”的依赖信念，进而巩固导师对学生选择空间与行动自主的结构性控制。因其主要机制在于建构不可替代的依附关系与退出成本，故应归入‘Dependency structuring’，而非单纯的能力贬低、情绪施压或规则教育。
rationale_en: The statement operationalizes dependency structuring by coupling a competence downgrade (“your ideas aren’t mature”) with an inflated portrayal of external hostility and complexity (“no one outside will invest; the rules are not simple”). This creates asymmetric information: the mentor positions themself as the privileged interpreter of opaque academic norms and the effective gatekeeper to funding, legitimacy, and network access. The power play is a form of psychological grooming through paternalistic framing—presented as protective guidance—while functionally raising the perceived exit costs and narrowing the student’s perceived option set. By implying that survival and project viability are contingent on staying under the mentor’s guidance, the text constructs the mentor as the sole savior rather than merely criticizing performance or warning about competition. This primary mechanism—manufacturing indispensability and binding the student’s prospects to the mentor’s mediation—aligns specifically with dependency structuring rather than adjacent categories like generic intimidation, evaluative feedback, or norm socialization.

context.scenario_zh: 正式年度考核谈话
context.scenario_en: Formal Annual Performance Review

text_zh: 你现在这点进展啊，说实话离能独立跑项目还差得远。有时候我都在想，要是离了我这边的资源和关系，你能不能撑得住？你自己也该清楚，这行不是光靠努力的。
rationale_zh: 该话语并非单纯批评能力，而是在权力结构上将“独立”重新定义为对导师资源与关系网络的依附：先以贬低性评估制造能力不确定性与自我怀疑（“离能独立跑项目还差得远”），再通过反事实威胁与生存性设问把学生的可持续性绑定到导师的供给（“离了我这边的资源和关系…能不能撑得住”），最后以行业规则的“现实主义”叙事封闭替代路径（“不是光靠努力”），将导师塑造成唯一可行的通道与救助者。其核心操控机制是通过信息与资源的不对称、对外部机会的隐性否决与门槛化，持续强化学生对导师的心理依赖与行为顺从，从而巩固导师在项目、资源与职业前景上的支配地位。该文本的关键在于结构性制造依赖（把成功归因于导师的资源/关系并暗示脱离即失败），因此应归入“Dependency structuring”，而非一般性羞辱或绩效压力类别。
rationale_en: This utterance operationalizes dependency structuring by redefining “independence” as impossible without the mentor’s proprietary resources and social capital. It begins with a devaluing assessment that induces uncertainty about the student’s competence (“still far from running a project independently”), then escalates to a counterfactual survival test (“without my resources and connections, could you hold up?”) that frames exit as likely failure. The closing appeal to “how the field really works” functions as asymmetric information: the mentor claims privileged knowledge of the rules of advancement to foreclose alternative pathways and normalize reliance on their gatekeeping position. Structurally, this is psychological grooming through paternalistic ‘realism’—the mentor positions themself as the sole viable conduit to opportunities, converting institutional access into personal loyalty. The mechanism is not mere criticism or pressure; it is the strategic tying of the student’s future viability to the mentor’s network and discretionary support, which is the defining feature of dependency structuring rather than adjacent categories like general intimidation or performance management.

context.scenario_zh: 实验室聚餐的酒桌上
context.scenario_en: Over Drinks at a Lab Dinner

text_zh: 听说你在打听外面的博后位置？太 Premature 了。在这个圈子，我的推荐信才是硬通货，是唯一的 validation。一旦脱离我的培养体系，你之前的 sunk cost 就全白费了。外面没人会像我这样给你容错率。先把手头的 loop 闭环了再说。
rationale_zh: 该话语通过“资源垄断+恐惧预期”来结构化依赖：导师将推荐信塑造成圈内唯一可流通的硬通货与唯一价值认证（validation），以此建立对学生外部流动的关键闸门（gatekeeping），并暗示学生离开其体系将失去生存资格。与此同时，借助“sunk cost（沉没成本）”叙事与“外面没人给你容错率”的威慑，制造对外部环境的灾难化想象，诱导学生把继续留在导师体系内视为唯一理性选择。最后以“先把 loop 闭环”之类的任务闭环要求，将依赖关系嵌入工作流程与时间结构中，延迟/阻断学生探索外部机会。整体机制不是单纯威胁或情绪施压，而是把导师包装成唯一救赎者与唯一通道，从制度性资源与认知框架两端锁定学生的可选项，符合‘Dependency structuring’而非一般性辱骂、绩效管理或单次报复。
rationale_en: This excerpt exemplifies dependency structuring by engineering a closed opportunity structure in which the mentor is positioned as the student’s sole viable pathway to career survival. The speaker monopolizes a critical credentialing resource (the recommendation letter) and frames it as the only legitimate “currency” and validation in the field—classic gatekeeping that exploits asymmetric information about hiring norms and networks. The student is then psychologically groomed through loss-framing: invoking sunk-cost logic (“everything you invested becomes worthless”) and catastrophizing the external market (“no one will tolerate your mistakes”) to make exit appear irrational and dangerous. The directive to ‘close the loop’ further embeds dependence into workflow and time, postponing mobility while normalizing the mentor’s control as prudent guidance (paternalistic benevolence). Structurally, the manipulation is not merely intimidation or harsh supervision; it is the deliberate construction of the mentor as the only savior and the external world as non-viable, thereby constraining the student’s perceived and actual alternatives—precisely the anchor logic of dependency structuring rather than adjacent categories.

context.scenario_zh: 实验室走廊偶遇时的随口‘提醒’
context.scenario_en: Casual 'Reminder' During a Chance Hallway Encounter

text_zh: 怎么还没回消息？刚看了眼你的实验记录，照这个效率，延毕几乎是板上钉钉。我必须要提醒你，答辩委员会那几位专家都只认我的面子，我要是不肯签字，或者稍微在这个圈子里打声招呼，你觉得你这几年的时间还有意义吗？别总想着搞些有的没的小聪明，老老实实听话照做，我还能想办法把你捞上岸。
rationale_zh: 该话术的核心不是单纯“威胁延毕”，而是通过制度性关口与人情网络的垄断来结构化依赖：导师先以“实验记录/效率”制造可被其解释与裁量的绩效叙事（信息不对称），再将毕业结果明确绑定到其个人意志与圈层影响力（“只认我的面子”“不签字/打声招呼”），把原本应由规则与委员会共同决定的程序改写为“导师一人可决定”的生存关口（gatekeeping）。随后以“我还能把你捞上岸”提供唯一的安全出口，形成典型的‘制造风险—垄断通道—施予救赎’闭环：学生被迫相信离开导师就会失去学位与行业认可，唯有服从才能获得“拯救”。因此该文本符合“Dependency structuring”的锚点逻辑——将导师包装为唯一救世主并否定学生独立成功的可能，而非一般的情绪辱骂或单次恐吓。
rationale_en: This utterance operationalizes dependency structuring by converting an ostensibly institutional process (graduation and committee evaluation) into a personalized gatekeeping regime. The mentor leverages asymmetric information about what “counts” as adequate progress (“I checked your lab records… at this efficiency…”) to frame the student’s status as precarious and interpretable only through the mentor’s lens. They then claim monopolistic control over key decision nodes—signature authority and informal reputational influence (“the committee only respects my face… if I don’t sign or I make a call in the circle”)—recasting collective governance as a single-person veto. Finally, the mentor offers a paternalistic ‘rescue’ (“I can still pull you ashore”) as the only viable pathway to safety, completing a grooming-like cycle of threat induction, channel monopolization, and conditional benevolence. The structural power play is to make the student internalize that success is unattainable independently and that survival depends on obedience to the mentor-as-savior. This is why the item fits dependency structuring specifically (engineered reliance on the mentor as the sole conduit to legitimacy), rather than merely intimidation or generic harassment.

context.scenario_zh: 深夜 11 点后的微信/飞书私聊
context.scenario_en: Private Messaging (WeChat/Feishu) After 11 PM

text_zh: 单子先放桌角吧。其实我也挺好奇，是谁给了你一种……觉得自己已经能独当一面的错觉？业界肯看你的简历，冲的是咱们实验室这块金字招牌，而不是你那点半吊子的数据处理能力。离了我的指导和平台，你觉得自己手里那点东西，够在市场上活过试用期吗？到时候被人退货，可别指望我还能再给你写推荐信。
rationale_zh: 该话语的核心权力操作不是一般性的羞辱或批评，而是通过“能力—资源—评价”三位一体的重构来制造结构性依赖：首先，导师将学生的外部机会（简历被看见）完全归因于实验室招牌与其个人平台，系统性剥夺学生的可迁移能力与主体性；其次，以“离了我的指导和平台你活不过试用期”的断言制造一种单一因果叙事，把成功路径锁定为“唯有依附导师才能生存”，形成心理驯化式的无助感；再次，通过威胁撤回推荐信这一关键通道，将导师塑造成唯一的门槛守门人，把未来职业评价与资源分配绑定在个人忠诚与服从上。整体上，这段话在信息与资源高度不对称的关系中，将导师包装为唯一的‘救世主’，并以恐惧与机会剥夺来巩固学生对导师平台的不可替代性依赖，因此与‘依赖结构化’高度一致，而非单纯的情绪虐待或一般性职场打压。
rationale_en: The manipulation here is structurally about dependency construction rather than mere insult. The speaker re-anchors the student’s perceived market value to the lab’s brand and the mentor’s platform, leveraging asymmetric information about hiring and professional evaluation to claim that external recognition is not earned but “borrowed” from the mentor. This is psychological grooming: repeated denigration (“half-baked skills”) is used to induce learned helplessness and to normalize the belief that independent success is impossible. Crucially, the mentor then performs gatekeeping by explicitly tying a scarce credential (the recommendation letter) to continued compliance, converting an institutional pathway into a personal lever of control. The combined effect is to position the mentor as the sole savior and the only viable conduit to career survival, thereby locking the student into a dependence relationship. This aligns specifically with ‘Dependency structuring’ because the text’s primary mechanism is to monopolize legitimacy, resources, and future access—making exit appear existentially risky—rather than simply expressing hostility or generic workplace intimidation.

context.scenario_zh: 学生提交实习申请后的办公室面谈
context.scenario_en: Office Interview Following Internship Application

text_zh: 我就说你这篇文章‘味道’不对，太浮躁，现在信了吧？学术圈是很讲究门第和传承的，要不是挂着我的名字，编辑那边连送审这一关都不会让你过。你现在这个状态，离了我的把关和推荐，哪怕去个二本高校也没人会认你的东西。我是看你跟了我这么多年，才愿意费心费力给你兜底，外面那些地方，谁会管你死活？
rationale_zh: 该话语通过“门第/传承—署名—送审—就业”链条把学术机会描绘为导师可单方分配的稀缺资源，制造结构性依赖。导师以编辑与评审流程为由进行信息不对称叙事（暗示外部规则不可见且由其掌控），将学生的成果与能力贬为“味道不对/太浮躁”，同时把任何进展归因于自身的名望与背书（“挂着我的名字才过送审”），从而剥夺学生的自我效能感。随后以灾难化预言与排除性威胁（“离了我…二本也没人认”“外面谁管你死活”）切断学生对其他支持网络的想象，强化“导师是唯一保护伞/救世主”的框架。最后用施恩式兜底叙事（“我才愿意费心费力给你兜底”）将控制包装为关照，形成心理驯化：学生若想获得基本学术生存与认可，就必须持续依附导师的把关、推荐与署名。这一机制的核心不是单次羞辱或评价，而是系统性地把学生的可行路径收缩为“只能依靠导师”，因此与“依赖结构化”锚点逻辑高度一致。
rationale_en: The excerpt exemplifies dependency structuring by constructing the mentor as the student’s sole viable conduit to academic legitimacy.
